title: DNS Cache Poisoning

profile.name: HackerOne
profile.about: Vulnerability disclosure should be safe, transparent, and rewarding.

vulnerability_information:
I noticed if I made a request to your website, intercepted the request, and added the header...
X-Forwarded-Host: evil.com
it would redirect me to evil.com. Well, after that, I tried going to hackerone.com and I was instantly redirected to evil.com. This is a result of DNS cache poisoning.

activities.message:
I was able to reproduce the first part of your report (getting redirected to `evil.com`). However, my browser did not instantly redirect me to `evil.com` when visiting `hackerone.com` again.

I'm aware of the cases described in [this article on host header attacks](http://www.skeletonscribe.net/2013/05/practical-http-host-header-attacks.html), but I believe we're not vulnerable. Can you provide more info why this would be an issue for HackerOne? Thanks!

activities.message:
Hi Michael, it turns out we're pretty lucky ;-)! As you can see [here](https://github.com/rails/rails/blob/3-2-stable/actionpack/lib/action_dispatch/http/url.rb#L97), this is something Rails does for us. Right now our root page returns a 302 and includes a caching header (`max-age=600, public`). CloudFlare [caches these 302s](https://support.cloudflare.com/hc/en-us/articles/200168326-Are-301-and-302-redirects-cached-by-CloudFlare-), but since we don't have a page rule for it the CF cache isn't poisoned. We ran...

```
$ curl -H 'X-Forwarded-Host: hackerone.com/ibb?test' https://hackerone.com
```

... for a while, but it keeps hitting our application servers and isn't cached. We don't think this was exploitable in our current configuration, but it was still a good find that made us nervous enough to harden this behavior. We pushed a fix to make sure we don't introduce this security vulnerability when we update CF caching rules.

Thanks again!
